Feb. 11, 1907
Los Angeles

The Eastside gets a new Baptist Church and 2nd Street and St. Louis.

Like Tom and Huck

A large pond 7 feet deep at Normandie and San Marino left by the runoff of recent rainstorms proved too tempting to the boys of the Forrester tract and so they launched a raft to play.

The raft tipped, The Times says, sending 8-year-old Clarence Rhodes of 1004 S. Jasmine tumbling into the water. Hearing the boysÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ cries for help, M. Allen rushed from his home at 922 Normandie, plunged into the water and rescued Clarence.

After nearly half an hourÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s work, the boy was resuscitated, The Times says.

Abandoned Boy

Ã¢â‚¬Å“His mother dead and deserted by his father, Charlie McDaniel, 6 years of age, has been wandering about the city, picking up a living as best he could, and sleeping in dry goods boxes and nooks and corners,Ã¢â‚¬Â The Times says. Ã¢â‚¬Å“The boy was found early yesterday morning by a patrolman and he is now in the Detention Home.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“In telling his pitiful story at the Central Station, the boy said that his mother died a few months ago and that his father had gone away with some woman. The police will make an effort to locate the father.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Last Stop

Mrs. A.C. Newton of 2707 Central Ave. is not expected to live after fracturing her skull when she leaped from a speeding streetcar because it passed her stop.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“According to witnesses, Mrs. Newton asked to be allowed to leave the car at 29th Street. When she saw the coach was running past the street, she jumped. The car crew carried her into a house nearby,Ã¢â‚¬Â The Times says.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Several passengers on the car said that it was No. 419. They state that the conductor paid no attention to Mrs. NewtonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s signals.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Note: I was amazed to learn just how many people were injured in 1907 by jumping from streetcars that failed to stop. Without checking further, I would say someone was hurt about once a week.

Bonus fact: The local tourism industry is furious because the state Senate passed the bill banning horses with docked tails. Businesses note that wealthy visitors from the East often bring their teams to Los Angeles at great expense and if their fancy horses are prohibited, wealthy tourists will avoid the Southland in favor of Florida.

Feb. 5, 2007
Sierra Madre

Because itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s celebrating its centennial this month, I paid a visit to Sierra Madre and while savoring a cinnamon dolce latte at the local Starbucks, watched the sun set on a historic Union 76 ball. A perfect fusion of two projects.

And hereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Sierra MadreÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Old North Church, with the artillery piece in the park across the street. Note the problem I encountered with lighting. Architectural photography is surely not my forte.

Now for the business at hand. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve often thought that with a century of lawmaking under its belt, the state Legislature might want to take the afternoon off. After all, with more than a century of making laws, whatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s left to regulate?

The Times provides a tidy answer to my question. Here’s what the Legislature was wrestling with 100 years ago:

Ã‚Â· The Senate unanimously passes a ban on docking horsesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ tails and prohibits anyone from bringing horses with docked tails into the state. Those who own horses with docked tails would have to register them with the local county officials.

Ã‚Â· The Senate passes a bill authorizing the governor to declare Ã¢â‚¬Å“Bud and Arbor Day.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã‚Â· The Senate passes a bill setting dairy standards and a bill to keep the polls open from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m.

Ã‚Â· A committee urges the Senate to pass Sen. BlackÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s tax exemption bill for all the buildings at Stanford as well as the bonds the university holds in trust.

Ã‚Â· Sen. Wolfe introduces a bill making all robberies committed with a deadly weapon between sunset and sunrise punishable by death or life in prison.

Ã‚Â· Assemblyman Grove L. Johnson introduces a Ã¢â‚¬Å“no seat, no fareÃ¢â‚¬Â bill providing that railroad passengers who cannot find a seat need not pay. The bill would include streetcars.

Ã‚Â· Assemblyman Johnson introduces a bill requiring firearms dealers to keep records of gun buyersÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ names and addresses.

Ã‚Â· The Assembly passes a bill by the late Assemblyman Burke making it illegal to spit on sidewalks or in trains, cars and other public conveyances.

Ã‚Â· Sen. Sanford introduces a bill seeking to restrict corporate donations to political campaigns. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m so glad the Senate wrapped that up 100 years ago so it can get on to more pressing matters.
